intro: Lappa bardana subsp. tomentosa, commonly known as the woolly lappa, is a flowering plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and stems, which give it a distinctive, fuzzy appearance. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the Asteraceae family. It thrives in moist, disturbed habitats such as meadows and riverbanks. Its botanical features make it easily identifiable and ecologically significant in its native range.
